abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Through the following
            lessons, it is suggested that the policy framework - macro
            and sectoral - conducive to reforms, should be in place
            prior to implementing a major institutional reform program,
            including a firm borrower commitment for institutional
            changes. Additionally, efficient, and effective water user
            associations - key to sustainable irrigation and
            agricultural development - need to be set at the early
            stages, involved in planning, design, and implementation
            levels. It is also suggested that, while projects should
            have a firmly time-bound program for institutional reform,
            in advance of a major investment project in capital works,
            the absence of such, could ideally, prod an initial project,
            or project phase, supporting institutional reform, and
            development, to be followed by a second project, or project
            phase in which the reformed institutions implement an
            investment works project. Finally, advance action, and
            readiness on the part of the borrower, or implementing
            agencies, are required for timely project implementation,
            and capacity building.
